sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Fasting days? What would you tell me of fasting days? 'Slid, would they were all on a light fire for me. They say, the whole world shall be consumed with fire one day, but would I had these Ember-weeks and villainous Fridays burnt, in the meantime, and then--

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Why, how now, Cob, what moves thee to this choler? Ha?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Collar, Master Thomas? I scorn your collar, I sir, I am none o' your cart-horse, though I carry, and draw water. An' you offer to ride me, with your collar, or halter either, I may hap show you a jade's trick, sir.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Oh, you'll slip your head out of the collar? Why, goodman Cob, you mistake me.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nay, I have my rheum, and I can be angry as well as another, sir.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Thy rheum, Cob? Thy humour, thy humour! Thou mistak'st.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Humour? Mack, I think it be so, indeed; what is that humour? Some rare thing, I warrant.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Marry, I'll tell thee, Cob: it is a gentleman-like monster, bred, in the special gallantry of our time, by affectation; and fed by folly.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: How? Must it be fed?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Oh, aye, humour is nothing, if it be not fed. Didst thou never hear that? It's a common phrase, 'Feed my humour'.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: I'll none on it: humour, avaunt, I know you not, begone. Let who will make hungry meals for your monstership, it shall not be I. Feed you, quoth he? 'Slid, I ha' much ado to feed myself; especially on these lean rascally days, too; an't had been any other day but a fasting day (a plague on them all for me), by this light, one might have done the commonwealth good service, and have drowned them all i' the flood, two or three hundred thousand years ago. Oh, I do stomach them hugely! I have a maw now, an' 'twere for Sir Bevis his horse, against 'em.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: I pray thee, good Cob, what makes thee so out of love with fasting days?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Marry, that which will make any man out of love with 'em, I think: their bad conditions, an' you will needs know. First, they are of a Flemish breed, I am sure on't, for they ravin up more butter than all the days of the week beside; next, they stink of fish and leek-porridge miserably; thirdly, they'll keep a man devoutly hungry all day, and at night send him supperless to bed.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Indeed, these are faults, Cob.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nay, an' this were all, 'twere something, but they are the only known enemies to my generation. A fasting day no sooner comes, but my lineage goes to rack, poor cobs, they smoke for it, they are made martyrs o' the gridiron, they melt in passion: and your maids too know this, and yet would have me turn Hannibal, and eat my own fish and blood. He pulls out a red herring My princely coz, fear nothing: I have not the heart to devour you, an' I might be made as rich as King Cophetua. Oh, that I had room for my tears, I could weep salt water enough, now, to preserve the lives of ten thousand of my kin. But I may curse none but these filthy almanacs, for an't were not for them, these days of persecution would ne'er be known. I'll be hanged, an' some fishmonger's son do not make of 'em; and puts in more fasting days than he should do, because he would utter his father's dried stock-fish, and stinking conger.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: 'Slight, peace, thou'lt be beaten like a stock-fish, else: here is Master Matthew. Now must I look out for a messenger to my master.

div2.head: Act III, Scene iii
div2.stage: [Enter] WELLBRED, EDWARD, BRAINWORM, BOBADILL, MATTHEW [and] STEPHEN

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Beshrew me, but it was an absolute good jest, and exceedingly well carried!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Aye, and our ignorance maintained it as well, did it not?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Yes, faith, but was't possible thou should'st not know him? I forgive Master Stephen, for he is stupidity itself!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: 'Fore God, not I, an' I might have been joined patent with one of the seven wise masters for knowing him. He had so writhen himself into the habit of one of your poor infantry, your decayed, ruinous, worm-eaten gentlemen of the round: such as have vowed to sit on the skirts of the city, let your Provost and his half-dozen of halberdiers do what they can; and have translated begging out of the old hackney pace, to a fine easy amble, and made it run as smooth of the tongue as a shove-groat shilling. Into the likeness of one of these reformados had he moulded himself so perfectly, observing every trick of their action, as varying the accent, swearing with an emphasis, indeed all, with so special and exquisite a grace that (hadst thou seen him) thou wouldst have sworn he might have been sergeant-major, if not lieutenant-colonel to the regiment.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Why, Brainworm, who would have thought thou hadst been such an artificer?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: An artificer! An architect! Except a man had studied begging all his lifetime, and been a weaver of language, from his infancy, for the clothing of it, I never saw his rival!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Where got'st thou this coat, I mar'l?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Of a Houndsditch man, sir. One of the devil's near kinsmen, a broker.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: That cannot be, if the proverb hold; for, a crafty knave needs no broker.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: True sir, but I did need a broker, ergo.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Well put off--no crafty knave, you'll say.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Tut, he has more of these shifts.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: And yet where I have one, the broker has ten, sir.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Francis, Martin, ne'er a one to be found, now? What a spite's this?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: How now, Thomas? Is my brother Kitely within?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: No sir, my master went forth e'en now; but Master Downright is within. Cob, what, Cob? Is he gone too?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Whither went your master, Thomas, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: I know not, to Justice Clement's, I think, sir. Cob!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Justice Clement, what's he?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Why, dost thou not know him? He is a city magistrate, a justice here, an excellent good lawyer, and a great scholar; but the only mad, merry, old fellow in Europe! I showed him you, the other day.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Oh, is that he? I remember him now. Good faith, and he has a very strange presence, methinks; it shows as if he stood out of the rank from other men. I have heard many of his jests i' university. They say, he will commit a man for taking the wall of his horse.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Aye, or wearing his cloak of one shoulder, or serving of God: anything indeed, if it come in the way of his humour.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Gasper, Martin, Cob! 'Heart, where should they be, trow?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Master Kitely's man, 'pray thee vouchsafe us the lighting of this match.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Fire on your match, no time but now to vouchsafe? Francis, Cob!

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Body of me! Here's the remainder of seven pound, since yesterday was seven-night. 'Tis your right Trinidado! Did you never take any, Master Stephen?

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: No truly, sir; but I'll learn to take it now, since you commend it, so.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Sir, believe me (upon my relation), for what I tell you, the world shall not reprove. I have been in the Indies (where this herb grows), where neither myself, nor a dozen gentlemen more (of my knowledge) have received the taste of any other nutriment in the world, for the space of one and twenty weeks, but the fume of this simple only. Therefore, it cannot be but 'tis most divine! Further, take it in the nature, in the true kind so, it makes an antidote that, had you taken the most deadly poisonous plant in all Italy, it should expel it, and clarify you, with as much ease as I speak. And, for your green wound, your Balsamum and your St. John's wort are all mere gulleries, and trash to it, especially your Trinidado; your Nicotian is good too. I could say what I know of the virtue of it, for the expulsion of rheums, raw humours, crudities, obstructions, with a thousand of this kind; but I profess myself no quacksalver. Only, thus much, by Hercules, I do hold it, and will affirm it (before any prince in Europe) to be the most sovereign and precious weed that ever the earth tendered to the use of man.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: This speech would ha' done decently in a tobacco-trader's mouth!

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: At Justice Clement's, he is: in the middle of Coleman Street.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Where's the match I gave thee? Master Kitely's man?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Would his match, and he, and pipe, and all were at Santo Domingo! I had forgot it.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p:
By God's me, I mar'l what pleasure or felicity they have in taking this roguish tobacco! It's good for nothing but to choke a man, and fill him full of smoke and embers: there were four died out of one house,
last week, with taking of it, and two more the bell went for yesternight; one of them (they say) will ne'er scape it: he voided a bushel of soot yesterday, upward and downward. By the stocks, an' there were no wiser men than I, I'd have it present whipping, man or woman, that should but deal with a tobacco-pipe; why, it will stifle them all in the end, as many as use it; it's little better than ratsbane, or rosaker.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Oh, good Captain, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: You base cullion, you.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Sir, here's your match;
come, thou must needs be talking, too, thou'rt well enough served.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nay, he will not meddle with his match, I warrant you: well, it shall be a dear beating, an' I live.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Do you prate? Do you murmur?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Nay, good Captain, will you regard the humour of a fool?
Away, knave.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Thomas, get him away.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: A whoreson filthy slave, a dung-worm, an excrement! Body o' Caesar, but that I scorn to let forth so mean a spirit, I'd ha' stabbed him to the earth.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Marry, the law forbid, sir.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: By Pharaoh's foot, I would have done it.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Oh, he swears admirably! By Pharaoh's foot! Body o' Caesar! I shall never do it, sure, upon mine honour, and by St. George, no, I ha' not the right grace.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Master Stephen, will you any? By this air, the most divine tobacco that ever I drunk!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: None, I thank you, sir.
Oh, this gentleman does it rarely too! But nothing like the other. By this air, as I am a gentleman: by-- Practising, to the post

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Master, glance, glance! Master Wellbred!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: As I have somewhat to be saved, I protest--

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: You are a fool; it needs no affidavit.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Cousin, will you any tobacco?

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Aye, sir! Upon my reputation--

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: How now, cousin!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: I protest, as I am a gentleman, but no soldier, indeed--

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: No, Master Stephen? As I remember, your name is entered in the Artillery Garden.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Aye, sir, that's true: cousin, may I swear, as I am a soldier, by that?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Oh yes, that you may. It's all you have for your money.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Then, as I am a gentleman, and a soldier, it is divine tobacco!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: But soft, where's Master Matthew? Gone?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: No, sir, they went in here.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, let's follow them: Master Matthew is gone to salute his mistress, in verse. We shall ha' the happiness to hear some of his poetry now. He never comes unfurnished. Brainworm?

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Brainworm? Where? Is this Brainworm?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Aye, cousin, no words of it, upon your gentility.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Not I, body of me, by this air, St. George, and the foot of Pharaoh!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Rare! Your cousin's discourse is simply drawn out with oaths.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: 'Tis larded with 'em. A kind of French dressing, if you love it.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Ha? How many are there, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Marry, sir, your brother, Master Wellbred--

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Tut, beside him: what strangers are there, man?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Strangers? Let me see, one, two: mass, I know not well, there are so many.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: How? So many?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Aye, there's some five, or six of them, at most.

sp.speaker: KITELY

lg.l: A swarm, a swarm,
Spite of the devil, how they sting my head
With forkèd stings, thus wide and large!

sp.stage: [He holds up fingers to indicate horns on his head]

lg.l: But, Cob,
How long hast thou been coming hither, Cob?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: A little while, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Didst thou come running?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Nay, then I am familiar with thy haste!

lg.l: Bane to my fortunes! What meant I to marry?
I, that before was ranked in such content,
My mind at rest too, in so soft a peace,
Being free master of mine own free thoughts,
And now become a slave? What? Never sigh,
Be of good cheer, man: for thou art a cuckold,
'Tis done, 'tis done! Nay, when such flowing store,
Plenty itself, falls in my wife's lap,
The cornu-copiae will be mine, I know. But, Cob,
What entertainment had they? I am sure
My sister, and my wife, would bid them welcome! Ha?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Like enough, sir, yet I heard not a word of it.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.l: No: their lips were sealed with kisses, and the voice
Drowned in a flood of joy, at their arrival,
Had lost her motion, state, and faculty.
Cob, which of them was't, that first kissed my wife?
My sister, I should say; my wife, alas,
I fear not her: ha? Who was it, say'st thou?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: By my troth, sir, will you have the truth of it?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Oh aye, good Cob: I pray thee, heartily.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Then, I am a vagabond, and fitter for Bridewell than your worship's company, if I saw anybody to be kissed, unless they would have kissed the post in the middle of the warehouse; for there I left them all, at their tobacco, with a pox.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: How? Were they not gone in, then, ere thou cam'st?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, no, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Spite of the devil! What do I stay here, then? Cob, follow me.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nay, soft and fair, I have eggs on the spit: I cannot go yet, sir. Now am I for some five and fifty reasons hammering, hammering revenge; oh, for three or four gallons of vinegar, to sharpen my wits. Revenge; vinegar revenge; vinegar and mustard revenge; nay, an' he had not lyen in my house, 'twould never have grieved me, but being my guest, one that I'll be sworn my wife has lent him her smock off her back, while his one shirt has been at washing; pawned her neckerchers for clean bands for him; sold almost all my platters, to buy him tobacco; and he to turn monster of ingratitude, and strike his lawful host! Well, I hope to raise up an host of fury for't: here comes Justice Clement.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: What, 's Master Kitely gone? Roger?

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: 'Heart o' me! What made him leave us so abruptly? How now, sirrah? What make you here? What would you have, ha?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: An't please your worship, I am a poor neighbour of your worship's--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: A poor neighbour of mine? Why, speak, poor neighbour.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: I dwell, sir, at the sign of the Water-tankard, hard by the Green Lattice: I have paid scot and lot there, any time this eighteen years.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: To the Green Lattice?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: No, sir, to the parish: marry, I have seldom scaped scot-free, at the Lattice.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Oh, well! What business has my poor neighbour with me?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: An't like your worship, I am come to crave the peace of your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Of me, knave? Peace of me, knave? Did I e'er hurt thee? Or threaten thee? Or wrong thee? Ha?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: No, sir, but your worship's warrant, for one that has wronged me, sir: his arms are at too much liberty, I would fain have them bound to a treaty of peace, an' my credit could compass it with your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Thou goest far enough about for't, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Why, dost thou go in danger of thy life for him, friend?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: No sir; but I go in danger of my death, every hour, by his means: an' I die within a twelve-month and a day, I may swear, by the law of the land, that he killed me.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: How? How knave? Swear he killed thee? And by the law? What pretence? What colour hast thou for that?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Marry, an't please your worship, both black and blue: colour enough, I warrant you. I have it here, to show your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: What is he that gave you this, sirrah?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: A gentleman, and a soldier, he says he is, o' the city here.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: A soldier o' the city? What call you him?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Captain Bobadill.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Bobadill? And why did he bob and beat you, sirrah? How began the quarrel betwixt you: ha? Speak truly, knave, I advise you.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Marry, indeed, an' please your worship, only because I spake against their vagrant tobacco, as I came by 'em, when they were taking on't; for nothing else.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Ha? You speak against tobacco? Formal, his name.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: What's your name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oliver, sir, Oliver Cob, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Tell Oliver Cob, he shall go to the jail, Formal.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Oliver Cob, my master, Justice Clement, says, you shall go to the jail.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, I beseech your worship, for God's sake, dear Master Justice.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Nay, God's precious: an' such drunkards, and tankards, as you are, come to dispute of tobacco once--I have done! Away with him.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, good Master Justice, sweet old gentleman.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Sweet Oliver, would I could do thee any good: Justice Clement, let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: What? A threadbare rascal! A beggar! A slave that never drunk out of better than piss-pot metal in his life! And he to deprave and abuse the virtue of an herb so generally received in the courts of princes, the chambers of nobles, the bowers of sweet ladies, the cabins of soldiers! Roger, away with him, by God's precious--I say, go to.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Dear Master Justice: let me be beaten again, I have deserved it; but not the prison, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Alas, poor Oliver!

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Roger, make him a warrant--he shall not go--I but fear the knave.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Do not stink, sweet Oliver, you shall not go, my master will give you a warrant.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, the Lord maintain his worship, his worthy worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Away, dispatch him. [Exeunt FORMAL and COB] How now, Master Knowell! In dumps? In dumps? Come, this becomes not.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Sir, would I could not feel my cares--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Your cares are nothing! They are like my cap, soon put on, and as soon put off. What? Your son is old enough to govern himself: let him run his course, it's the only way to make him a staid man. If he were an unthrift, a ruffian, a drunkard, or a licentious liver, then you had reason: you had reason to take care; but, being none of these, mirth's my witness, an' I had twice so many cares as you have, I'd drown them all in a cup of sack. Come, come, let's try it; I muse your parcel of a soldier returns not all this while.

div2.head: Act IV, Scene i

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Well, sister, I tell you true; and you'll find it so, in the end.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Alas, brother, what would you have me to do? I cannot help it: you see, my brother brings 'em in here, they are his friends.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: His friends? His fiends. 'Slud, they do nothing but haunt him, up and down, like a sort of unlucky sprites, and tempt him to all manner of villainy that can be thought of. Well, by this light, a little thing would make me play the devil with some of 'em; an't were not more for your husband's sake than anything else, I'd make the house too hot for the best on 'em: they should say, and swear, hell were broken loose ere they went hence. But, by God's will, 'tis nobody's fault but yours: for, an' you had done as you might have done, they should have been parboiled, and baked too, every mother's son, ere they should ha' come in, e'er a one of 'em.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: God's my life! Did you ever hear the like? What a strange man is this! Could I keep out all them, think you? I should put myself against half a dozen men, should I? Good faith, you'd mad the patient'st body in the world, to hear you talk so, without any sense or reason!

div2.stage: [Enter] MISTRESS BRIDGET, MASTER MATTHEW, [and] BOBADILL, [followed by] WELLBRED, STEPHEN, EDWARD [and] BRAINWORM

lg.l: Servant, in troth, you are too prodigal
Of your wit's treasure, thus to pour it forth
Upon so mean a subject as my worth.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: You say well, mistress; and I mean as well.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Hoy-day, here is stuff!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, now stand close; pray heaven she can get him to read; he should do it of his own natural impudency.

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Servant, what is this same, I pray you?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Marry, an elegy, an elegy, an odd toy--

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: To mock an ape withal. Oh, I could sew up his mouth now.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Sister, I pray you let's hear it.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Are you rhyme-given, too?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Mistress, I'll read it, if you please.

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Pray you do, servant.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Oh, here's no foppery! Death, I can endure the stocks better.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: What ails thy brother? Can he not hold his water at reading of a ballad?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, no: a rhyme to him is worse than cheese or a bagpipe. But, mark, you lose the protestation.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Faith, I did it in an humour: I know not how it is; but, please you come near, sir. This gentleman has judgement, he knows how to censure of a--pray you sir, you can judge.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Not I, sir: upon my reputation, and by the foot of Pharaoh.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, chide your cousin for swearing.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Not I, so long as he does not forswear himself.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Master Matthew, you abuse the expectation of your dear mistress, and her fair sister: fie, while you live, avoid this prolixity.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: I shall, sir: well, Incipere dulce.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: How! Insipere dulce? A sweet thing to be a fool, indeed.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: What, do you take Incipere in that sense?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: You do not? You? This was your villainy, to gull him with a mot.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, the benchers' phrase: pauca verba, pauca verba.

lg.l: Rare creature, let me speak without offence,
Would God my rude words had the influence,
To rule thy thoughts, as thy fair looks do mine,
Then should'st thou be his prisoner, who is thine.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: This is in Hero and Leander?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, ay! Peace, we shall have more of this.

lg.l: Be not unkind and fair, misshapen stuff
Is of behaviour boisterous, and rough.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: How like you that, sir?

div2.stage: MASTER STEPHEN answers with shaking his head

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: 'Slight, he shakes his head like a bottle, to feel and there be any brain in it!

lg.l: But observe the catastrophe, now:
And I in duty will exceed all other,
As you in beauty do excel love's mother.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Well, I'll have him free of the wit-brokers, for he utters nothing but stol'n remnants.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, forgive it him.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: A filching rogue? Hang him. And from the dead? It's worse than sacrilege.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Sister, what ha' you here? Verses? Pray you, let's see. Who made these verses? They are excellent good!

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Oh, Master Wellbred, 'tis your disposition to say so sir. They were good i' the morning, I made 'em, extempore, this morning.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: How? Extempore?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: I would I might be hanged else; ask Captain Bobadill. He saw me write them, at the--(pox on it) the Star, yonder.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Can he find, in his heart, to curse the stars so?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Faith, his are even with him: they ha' cursed him enough already.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Cousin, how do you like this gentleman's verses?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Oh, admirable! The best that ever I heard, coz!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Body o' Caesar! They are admirable! The best that ever I heard, as I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: I am vexed, I can hold ne'er a bone of me still! Heart! I think they mean to build and breed here!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Sister, you have a simple servant here, that crowns your beauty with such encomions, and devices; you may see what it is to be the mistress of a wit that can make your perfections so transparent that every blear eye may look through them, and see him drowned over head and ears, in the deep well of desire. Sister Kitely, I marvel you get you not a servant that can rhyme and do tricks, too.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Oh, monster! Impudence itself! Tricks?

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Tricks, brother? What tricks?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Nay, speak, I pray you, what tricks?

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Aye, never spare anybody here; but say, what tricks?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Passion of my heart! Do tricks?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: 'Slight, here's a trick vied, and revied! Why, you monkeys, you! What a caterwauling do you keep? Has he not given you rhymes, and verses, and tricks?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Oh, the fiend!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Nay, you, lamp of virginity, that take it in snuff so! Come and cherish this tame 'poetical fury' in your servant, you'll be begged else, shortly, for a concealment: go to, reward his muse. You cannot give him less than a shilling, in conscience, for the book he had it out of cost him a teston, at least. How now, gallants? Master Matthew? Captain? What? All sons of silence? No spirit?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Come, you might practice your ruffian-tricks somewhere else, and not here, I wuss: this is no tavern, nor drinking-school, to vent your exploits in.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: How now! Whose cow has calved?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Marry, that has mine, sir. Nay, boy, never look askance at me for the matter; I'll tell you of it, aye, sir, you, and your companions, mend yourselves, when I ha' done.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: My companions?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Yes sir, your companions, so I say, I am not afraid of you, nor them neither: your hang-bys here. You must have your poets, and your potlings, your soldados, and foolados, to follow you up and down the city, and here they must come to domineer, and swagger. [To MATTHEW and BOBADILL] Sirrah, you, ballad-singer, and slops, your fellow there, get you out: get you home; or, by this steel, I'll cut off your ears, and that presently.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: 'Slight, stay, let's see what he dare do: cut off his ears? Cut a whetstone. You are an ass, do you see? Touch any man here, and by this hand, I'll run my rapier to the hilts in you.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Yea, that would I fain see, boy. They all draw, and they of the house make out to part them

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Oh Jesu! Murder! Thomas, Gaspar!

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Help, help, Thomas.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Gentlemen, forebear, I pray you.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Well, sirrah, you, Holofernes: by my hand, I will pink your flesh full of holes with my rapier for this; I will, by this good heaven. They offer to fight again, and are parted Nay, let him come, let him come, gentlemen, by the body of St. George, I'll not kill him.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Hold, hold, good gentlemen.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: You whoreson, bragging coistril.

lg.l: Why, how now? What's the matter? What's the stir here?
Whence springs this quarrel? Thomas! Where is he?
Put up your weapons, and put off this rage.
My wife and sister, they are the cause of this--
What, Thomas? Where is this knave?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Come, let's go: this is one of my brother's ancient humours, this.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: I am glad nobody was hurt by his ancient humour.

div2.stage: [Exeunt WELLBRED, STEPHEN, EDWARD, MATTHEW, BOBADILL and BRAINWORM]

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Why, how now, brother, who enforced this brawl?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: A sort of lewd rakehells, that care neither for God, nor the devil! And they must come here to read ballads, and roguery, and trash! I'll mar the knot of 'em ere I sleep, perhaps; especially Bob, there: he that's all manner of shapes! And 'Songs and Sonnets', his fellow.

lg.l: Brother, indeed, you are too violent,
Too sudden, in your humour; and you know
My brother Wellbred's temper will not bear
Any reproof, chiefly in such a presence,
Where every slight disgrace he should receive
Might wound him in opinion and respect.
Respect? What talk you of respect 'mong such,
As ha' nor spark of manhood, nor good manners?
'Sdeynes, I am ashamed to hear you! Respect?
Yes, there was one a civil gentleman,
And very worthily demeaned himself!
Oh, that was some love of yours, sister!
A love of mine? I would it were no worse, brother!
You'd pay my portion sooner than you think for.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Indeed, he seemed to be a gentleman of an exceeding fair disposition, and of very excellent good parts!

lg.l: Her love, by heaven! My wife's minion!
Fair disposition? Excellent good parts?
Death, these phrases are intolerable!
Good parts? How should she know his parts?
His parts? Well, well, well, well, well, well!
It is too plain, too clear. Thomas, come hither.
What, are they gone?
Aye, sir, they went in.
My mistress, and your sister--
Are any of the gallants within?
No, sir, they are all gone.
Art thou sure of it?
I can assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: What gentleman was that they praised so, Thomas?

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: One, they call him Master Knowell, a handsome young gentleman, sir.

lg.l: Aye, I thought so: my mind gave me as much.
I'll die but they have hid him i' the house,
Somewhere; I'll go and search. Go with me, Thomas.
Be true to me, and thou shalt find me a master.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: What, Tib! Tib, I say!

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: How now, what cuckold is that knocks so hard? [Opens the door] Oh, husband, is't you? What's the news?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nay, you have stunned me, i' faith! You ha' giv'n me a knock o' the forehead will stick by me! Cuckold? 'Slid, cuckold?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p:
Away, you fool, did I know it was you, that knocked?
Come, come, you may call me as bad, when you list.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: May I? Tib, you are a whore.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: You lie in your throat, husband.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: How, the lie? And in my throat too? Do you long to be stabbed, ha?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Why, you are no soldier, I hope?

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, must you be stabbed by a soldier? Mass, that's true! When was Bobadill here? Your captain? That rogue, that foist, that fencing Burgullian? I'll tickle him, i' faith.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Why, what's the matter? Trow!

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Oh, he has basted me, rarely, sumptuously! But I have it here in black and white,

for his black and blue, shall pay him. Oh, the Justice! The honestest old brave Trojan in London! I do honour the very flea of his dog. A plague on him though, he put me once in a villainous filthy fear; marry, it vanished away, like the smoke of tobacco; but I was smoked soundly first. I thank the devil, and his good angel, my guest. Well, wife, or Tib (which you will), get you in, and lock the door, I charge you, let nobody in to you; wife, nobody in to you: those are my words. Not Captain Bob himself, nor the fiend in his likeness; you are a woman; you have flesh and blood enough in you, to be tempted: therefore, keep the door, shut upon all comers.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: I warrant you, there shall nobody enter here, without my consent.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Nor with your consent, sweet Tib, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: It's more than you know, whether you leave me so.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Why, sweet.

lg.l: Tut, sweet, or sour, thou art a flower,
Keep close thy door, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Well, Brainworm, perform this business happily, and thou makest a purchase of my love forever.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: I' faith, now let thy spirits use their best faculties. But, at any hand, remember the message to my brother: for there's no other means to start him.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I warrant you, sir, fear nothing: I have a nimble soul has waked all forces of my fancy, by this time, and put 'em in true motion. What you have possessed me withal, I'll discharge it amply, sir. Make it no question.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Forth, and prosper, Brainworm. [Exit BRAINWORM] Faith, Ned, how dost thou approve of my abilities in this device?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Troth, well, howsoever; but it will come excellent, if it take.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Take, man? Why, it cannot choose but take, if the circumstances miscarry not; but, tell me, ingenuously, dost thou affect my sister Bridget, as thou pretend'st?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Friend, am I worth belief?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Come, do not protest. In faith, she is a maid of good ornament, and much modesty; and, except I conceived very worthily of her, thou shouldest not have her.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Nay, that I am afraid will be a question yet, whether I shall have her, or no.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: 'Slid, thou shalt have her: by this light, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Nay, do not swear.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: By this hand, thou shalt have her: I'll go fetch her, presently. Point but where to meet, and as I am an honest man, I'll bring her.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Hold, hold, be temperate.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Why, by--what shall I swear by? Thou shalt have her, as I am--

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: 'Pray thee, be at peace, I am satisfied; and do believe thou wilt omit no offered occasion to make my desires complete.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Thou shalt see, and know, I will not.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Was your man a soldier, sir?

lg.l: Aye, a knave, I took him begging o' the way,
This morning, as I came over Moorfields!
Oh, here he is! You've made fair speed, believe me:
Where, i' the name of sloth, could you be thus--

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Marry, peace be my comfort, where I thought I should have had little comfort of your worship's service.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Oh, sir! Your coming to the city, your entertainment of me, and your sending me to watch--indeed, all the circumstances either of your charge, or my employment--are as open to your son as to yourself!

lg.l: How should that be! Unless that villain, Brainworm,
Have told him of the letter, and discovered
All that I strictly charged him to conceal? 'Tis so!

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I am partly o' the faith 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: But, how should he know thee to be my man?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Nay, sir, I cannot tell; unless it be by the black art! Is not your son a scholar, sir?

lg.l: Yes, but I hope his soul is not allied
Unto such hellish practices: if it were,
I had just cause to weep my part in him,
And curse the time of his creation.
But, where didst thou find them, Fitzsword?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: You should rather ask, where they found me, sir, for I'll be sworn I was going along in the street, thinking nothing, when (of a sudden) a voice calls, 'Master Knowell's man'; another cries, 'Soldier'; and thus, half a dozen of 'em, till they had called me within a house where I no sooner came but they seemed men, and out flew all their rapiers at my bosom, with some three- or four-score oaths to accompany 'em, and all to tell me I was but a dead man, if I did not confess where you were, and how I was employed, and about what; which, when they could not get out of me (as I protest, they must ha' dissected and made an anatomy o' me first, and so I told 'em) they locked me up into a room i' the top of a high house, whence, by great miracle (having a light heart) I slid down, by a bottom of packthread, into the street, and so 'scaped. But, sir, thus much I can assure you, for I heard it while I was locked up, there were a great many rich merchants, and brave citizens' wives with 'em at a feast, and your son, Master Edward, withdrew with one of 'em, and has 'pointed to meet her anon, at one Cob's house, a water-bearer that dwells by the wall. Now, there your worship shall be sure to take him, for there he preys, and fail he will not.

lg.l: Nor will I fail, to break his match, I doubt not.
Go thou along with Justice Clement's man,
And stay there for me. At one Cob's house, say'st thou?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Aye, sir, there you shall have him.

Yes? Invisible? Much wench, or much son! 'Slight, when he has stayed there, three or four hours, travailing with the expectation of wonders, and at length be delivered of air; oh, the sport that I should then take, to look on him, if I durst! But now I mean to appear no more afore him in this shape. I have another trick to act yet. Oh, that I were so happy as to light on a nupson, now, of this Justice's novice.
Sir, I make you stay somewhat long.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Not a whit, sir. 'Pray you, what do you mean? Sir?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I was putting up some papers--

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: You ha' been lately in the wars, sir, it seems.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Marry have I, sir; to my loss; and expense of all, almost--

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: Troth, sir, I would be glad to bestow a pottle of wine o' you, if it please you to accept it--

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Oh, sir-

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: But to hear the manner of your services, and your devices in the wars, they say they be very strange, and not like those a man reads in the Roman histories, or sees at Mile End.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: No, I assure you, sir; why, at any time when it please you, I shall be ready to discourse to you, all I know;
and more too, somewhat.

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: No better time than now, sir: we'll go to the Windmill; there we shall have a cup of neat grist, we call it. I pray you, sir, let me request you to the Windmill.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I'll follow you, sir,
and make grist o' you, if I have good luck.

div2.head: Act IV, Scene v

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Sir, did your eyes ever taste the like clown of him, where we were today, Master Wellbred's half-brother? I think the whole earth cannot show his parallel, by this daylight.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: We were now speaking of him: Captain Bobadill tells me he is fall'n foul o' you, too.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Oh, aye, sir, he threatened me with the bastinado.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Aye, but I think I taught you prevention, this morning, for that-- You shall kill him, beyond question; if you be so generously minded.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Indeed, it is a most excellent trick! Practices at a post

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Oh, you do not give spirit enough to your motion, you are too tardy, too heavy! Oh, it must be done like lightning: hai!

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Rare, Captain!

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Tut, 'tis nothing an't be not done in a--punto!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Captain, did you ever prove yourself upon any of our masters of defence, here?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Oh, good sir! Yes, I hope, he has.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: I will tell you, sir. Upon my first coming to the city, after my long travail for knowledge (in that mystery only), there came three or four of 'em to me, at a gentleman's house, where it was my chance to be resident at that time, to entreat my presence at their schools, and withal so much importuned me that (I protest to you as I am a gentleman) I was ashamed of their rude demeanour, out of all measure. Well, I told 'em that to come to a public school, they should pardon me, it was opposite (in diameter) to my humour, but, if so they would give their attendance at my lodging, I protested to do them what right or favour I could, as I was a gentleman, and so forth.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: So, sir, then you tried their skill?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Alas, soon tried! You shall hear sir. Within two or three days after, they came; and, by honesty, fair sir, believe me, I graced them exceedingly, showed them some two or three tricks of prevention have purchased 'em, since, a credit, to admiration! They cannot deny this; and yet now, they hate me, and why? Because I am excellent, and for no other vile reason on the earth.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: This is strange, and barbarous, as ever I heard!

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Nay, for a more instance of their preposterous natures, but note, sir. They have assaulted me some three, four, five, six of them together, as I have walked alone, in divers skirts i' the town, as Turnbull, Whitechapel, Shoreditch, which were then my quarters, and since upon the Exchange, at my lodging, and at my ordinary; where I have driven them afore me, the whole length of a street, in the open view of all our gallants, pitying to hurt them, believe me. Yet, all this lenity will not o'ercome their spleen: they will be doing with the pismire, raising a hill a man may spurn abroad, with his foot, at pleasure. By myself, I could have slain them all, but I delight not in murder. I am loath to bear any other than this bastinado for 'em; yet, I hold it good polity not to go disarmed, for though I be skilful, I may be oppressed with multitudes.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Aye, believe me, may you sir; and (in my conceit) our whole nation should sustain the loss by it, if it were so.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Alas, no: what's a peculiar man, to a nation? Not seen.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Oh, but your skill, sir!

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Indeed, that might be some loss; but, who respects it? I will tell you, sir, by the way of private, and under seal; I am a gentleman, and live here obscure, and to myself; but, were I known to Her Majesty and the Lords (observe me) I would undertake (upon this poor head, and life), for the public benefit of the state, not only to spare the entire lives of her subjects in general, but to save the one half, nay, three parts of her yearly charge in holding war, and against what enemy soever. And, how would I do it, think you?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Nay, I know not, nor can I conceive.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Why, thus, sir. I would select nineteen more, to myself, throughout the land: gentlemen they should be of good spirit, strong, and able constitution, I would choose them by an instinct, a character, that I have; and I would teach these nineteen the special rules, as your punto, your reverso, your stoccata, your imbroccata, your passada, your montanto; till they could all play very near, or altogether as well as myself. This done, say the enemy were forty thousand strong, we twenty would come into the field, the tenth of March, or thereabouts; and we would challenge twenty of the enemy; they could not, in their honour, refuse us; well, we would kill them; challenge twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them too; and thus would we kill, every man, his twenty a day, that's twenty score; twenty score, that's two hundred; two hundred a day, five days a thousand; forty thousand; forty times five, five times forty, two hundred days kills them all up, by computation. And this will I venture my poor gentleman-like carcass to perform (provided there be no treason practiced upon us) by fair and discreet manhood, that is, civilly by the sword.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Why, are you so sure of your hand, Captain, at all times?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Tut, never miss thrust, upon my reputation with you.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: I would not stand in Downright's state, then, an' you meet him, for the wealth of any one street in London.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Why, sir, you mistake me! If he were here now, by this welkin, I would not draw my weapon on him! Let this gentleman do his mind; but, I will bastinado him (by the bright sun) wherever I meet him.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Faith, and I'll have a fling at him, at my distance.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: God's so', look where he is: yonder he goes.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Walks over the stage What peevish luck have I, I cannot meet with those bragging rascals?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: It's not he? Is it?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes, faith, it is he.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: I'll be hanged, then, if that were he.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Sir, keep your hanging good for some greater matter, for I assure you, that was he.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Upon my reputation, it was he.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Had I thought it had been he, he must not have gone so; but I can hardly be induced to believe it was he, yet.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: That I think, sir. But see, he is come again!

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Oh, Pharaoh's foot, have I found you? Come, draw, to your tools: draw, gipsy, or I'll thrash you.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Gentleman of valour, I do believe in thee, hear me--

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Draw your weapon, then.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Tall man, I never thought on it till now (body of me): I had a warrant of the peace served on me, even now, as I came along, by a water-bearer; this gentleman saw it, Master Matthew.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you will not draw, then?

div2.stage: He beats him, and disarms him: MATTHEW runs away

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Hold, hold, under thy favour, forbear.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Prate again, as you like this, you whoreson foist, you. You'll control the point, you? Your consort is gone? Had he stayed, he had shared with you, sir.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, bear witness, I was bound to the peace, by this good day.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: No, faith, it's an ill day, Captain, never reckon it other; but say you were bound to the peace, the law allows you to defend yourself: that'll prove but a poor excuse.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir. I desire good construction, in fair sort. I never sustained the like disgrace (by heaven), sure I was struck with a planet thence, for I had no power to touch my weapon.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Aye, like enough, I have heard of many that have been beaten under a planet: go, get you to a surgeon.

'Slid, an' these be your tricks, your passadas, and your montantos, I'll none of them. Oh, manners! That this
age should bring forth such creatures! That nature should be at leisure to make' em! Come, coz.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Mass, I'll ha' this cloak.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: God's will, 'tis Downright's.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Nay, it's mine now, another might have ta'en up, as well as I: I'll wear it, so I will.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: How an' he see it? He'll challenge it, assure yourself.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Aye, but he shall not ha' it: I'll say I bought it.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Take heed you buy it not too dear, coz.

div2.head: Act IV, Scene vi

lg.l: Now, trust me brother, you were much to blame,
T' incense his anger, and disturb the peace
Of my poor house, where there are sentinels
That every minute watch, to give alarms
Of civil war, without adjection
Of your assistance, or occasion.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: No harm done, brother, I warrant you: since there is no harm done. Anger costs a man nothing; and a tall man is never his own man, till he be angry. To keep his valour in obscurity is to keep himself, as it were, in a cloak-bag. What's a musician, unless he play? What's a tall man, unless he fight? For, indeed, all this my wise brother stands upon, absolutely; and that made me fall in with him so resolutely.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Aye, but what harm might have come of it, brother?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Might, sister? So, might the good warm clothes your husband wears be poisoned, for anything he knows; or the wholesome wine he drunk, even now, at the table--

lg.l: Now, God forbid: Oh me. Now I remember,
My wife drunk to me, last; and changed the cup;
And bade me wear this cursed suit today.
See if Heav'n suffer murder undiscovered!
I feel me ill: give me some mithridate,
Some mithridate and oil, good sister, fetch me;
Oh, I am sick at heart! I burn, I burn.
If you will save my life, go, fetch it me.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Oh, strange humour! My very breath has poisoned him.

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Good brother, be content, what do you mean? The strength of these extreme conceits will kill you.

lg.l: Beshrew your heart-blood, brother Wellbred, now,
For putting such a toy into his head.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Is a fit simile, a toy? Will he be poisoned with a simile? Brother Kitely, what a strange and idle imagination is this? For shame, be wiser. O' my soul, there's no such matter.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Am I not sick? How am I, then, not poisoned? Am I not poisoned? How am I, then, so sick?

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: If you be sick, your own thoughts make you sick.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: His jealousy is the poison he has taken.

div2.stage: [Enter] BRAINWORM. He comes disguised like Justice Clement's man.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Master Kitely, my master, Justice Clement, salutes you; and desires to speak with you, with all possible speed.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: No time but now? When, I think, I am sick? Very sick! Well, I will wait upon his worship. Thomas! Cob!
I must seek them out, and set 'em sentinels, till I return. Thomas! Cob! Thomas!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: This is perfectly rare, Brainworm! But how got'st thou this apparel, of the Justice's man?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Marry sir, my proper fine pen-man would needs bestow the grist o' me, at the Windmill, to hear some martial discourse, where so I marshalled him that I made him drunk with admiration! And, because too much heat was the cause of his distemper, I stripped him stark naked, as he lay along asleep, and borrowed his suit, to deliver this counterfeit message in, leaving a rusty armour and an old brown bill to watch him, till my return; which shall be, when I ha' pawned his apparel, and spent the better part o' the money, perhaps.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Well, thou art a successful merry knave, Brainworm, his absence will be a good subject for more mirth. I pray thee, return to thy young master, and will him to meet me, and my sister Bridget, at the Tower instantly: for here, tell him, the house is so stored with jealousy, there is no room for love to stand upright in. We must get our fortunes committed to some larger prison, say; and, than the Tower, I know no better air; nor where the liberty of the house may do us more present service. Away.

lg.l: Come hither, Thomas. Now, my secret's ripe,
And thou shalt have it: lay to both thine ears.
Hark what I say to thee. I must go forth, Thomas.
Be careful of thy promise, keep good watch,
Note every gallant, and observe him well,
That enters in my absence, to thy mistress:
If she would show him rooms, the jest is stale,
Follow 'em, Thomas, or else hang on him,
And let him not go after; mark their looks;
Note if she offer but to see his band,
Or any other amorous toy, about him;
But praise his leg, or foot; or if she say,
The day is hot, and bid him feel her hand,
How hot it is: oh, that's a monstrous thing!
Note me all this, good Thomas, mark their sighs,
And, if they do but whisper, break 'em off:
I'll bear thee out in it. Wilt thou do this?
Will thou be true, my Thomas?
As truth's self, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Why, I believe thee; where is Cob, now? Cob?

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: He's ever calling for Cob! I wonder how he employs Cob so!

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Indeed, sister, to ask how he employs Cob is a necessary question for you, that are his wife, and a thing not very easy for you to be satisfied in; but this I'll assure you, Cob's wife is an excellent bawd, sister, and oftentimes your husband haunts her house, marry, to what end, I cannot altogether accuse him, imagine you what you think convenient. But, I have known fair hides have foul hearts ere now, sister.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: Never said you truer than that, brother, so much I can tell you for your learning. Thomas, fetch your cloak, and go with me, I'll after him presently.
I would to fortune I could take him there, i' faith. I'd return him his own, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: So, let 'em go: this may make sport anon. Now, my fair sister-in-law, that you knew but how happy a thing it were to be fair and beautiful!

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: That touches not me, brother.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: That's true; that's even the fault of it: for, indeed, beauty stands a woman in no stead, unless it procure her touching. But, sister, whether it touch you or no, it touches your beauties; and I am sure they will abide the touch. An' they do not, a plague of all ceruse, say I; and it touches me too in part, though not in the--Well, there's a dear and respected friend of mine, sister, stands very strongly, and worthily affected toward you, and hath vowed to inflame whole bonfires of zeal, at his heart, in honour of your perfections. I have already engaged my promise to bring you where you shall hear him confirm much more. Ned Knowell is the man, sister. There's no exception against the party. You are ripe for a husband; and a minute's loss to such an occasion is a great trespass in a wise beauty. What say you, sister? On my soul he loves you. Will you give him the meeting?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Faith, I had very little confidence in mine own constancy, brother, if I durst not meet a man; but this motion of yours savours of an old knight-adventurer's servant a little too much, methinks.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: What's that, sister?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: Marry, of the squire.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: No matter if it did, I would be such an one for my friend, but see who is returned to hinder us!

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p:
What villainy is this? Called out on a false message? There was some plot! I was not sent for. Bridget,
where's your sister?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: I think she be gone forth, sir.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: How! Is my wife gone forth? Whither, for God's sake?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: She's gone abroad with Thomas.

lg.l: Abroad with Thomas? Oh, that villain dors me.
He hath discovered all unto my wife!
Beast that I was to trust him; whither, I pray you, went she?

sp.speaker: BRIDGET
sp.p: I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: I'll tell you, brother, whither I suspect she's gone.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Whither, good brother?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: To Cob's house, I believe; but, keep my counsel.

lg.l: I will, I will; to Cob's house? Doth she haunt Cob's?
She's gone a' purpose, now, to cuckold me,
With that lewd rascal, who, to win her favour,
Hath told her all.
Come, he's once more gone.
Sister, let's lose no time: th' affair is worth it.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: I wonder, Captain, what they will say of my going away? Ha?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Why, what should they say, but as of a discreet gentleman? Quick, wary, respectful of nature's fair lineaments; and that's all.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Why, so! But what can they say of your beating?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: A rude part, a touch with soft wood, a kind of gross battery used, laid on strongly, borne most patiently; and that's all.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Aye, but would any man have offered it in Venice, as you say?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Tut, I assure you, no: you shall have there your Nobilis, your Gentilezza, come in bravely upon your reverse, stand you close, stand you firm, stand you fair, save your retricato with his left leg, come to the assalto with the right, thrust with brave steel, defy your base wood! But wherefore do I awake this remembrance? I was fascinated, by Jupiter, fascinated: but I will be unwitched, and revenged, by law.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Do you hear? Is't not best to get a warrant, and have him arrested, and brought before Justice Clement?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: It were not amiss: would we had it.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Why, here comes his man, let's speak to him.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Agreed, do you speak.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Save you, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: With all my heart, sir.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p:
Sir, there is one Downright hath abused this gentleman, and myself, and we determine to make our amends by law; now, if you would do us the favour to procure a warrant, to bring afore your master,
you shall be well considered, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Sir, you know my service is my living: such favours as these, gotten of my master, is his only preferment; and therefore you must consider me, as I may make benefit of my place.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: How is that, sir?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Faith, sir, the thing is extraordinary, and the gentleman may be of great accompt; yet, be what he will, if you will lay me down a brace of angels in my hand, you shall have it, otherwise not.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: How shall we do, Captain? He asks a brace of angels, you have no money?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Not a cross, by fortune.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Nor I, as I am a gentleman, but twopence, left of my two shillings in the morning for wine and radish: let's find him some pawn.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Pawn? We have none to the value of his demand.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Oh, yes. I'll pawn this jewel in my ear, and you may pawn your silk stockings, and pull up your boots, they will ne'er be missed; it must be done now.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Well, an' there be no remedy; I'll step aside, and pull 'em off.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Do you hear, sir? We have no store of money at this time, but you shall have good pawns: look you, sir, this jewel, and that gentleman's silk stockings, because we would have it dispatched ere we went to our chambers.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I am content, sir: I will get you the warrant presently; what's his name, say you? Downright?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Aye, aye, George Downright.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: A tall big man, sir; he goes in a cloak, most commonly, of silk russet, laid about with russet lace.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: 'Tis very good, sir.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Here sir, here's my jewel.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: And here are stockings.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I'll procure you this warrant presently, but who will you have to serve it?

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: That's true, Captain; that must be considered.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Body o' me, I know not! 'Tis service of danger!

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Why, you were best get one o' the varlets o' the city, a sergeant. I'll appoint you one, if you please.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Will you, sir? Why, we can wish no better.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: We'll leave it to you, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: This is rare! Now will I go pawn this cloak of the Justice's man's at the brokers for a varlet's suit, and be the varlet myself; and get either more pawns, or more money of Downright, for the arrest.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Oh, here it is, I am glad: I have found it now. Ho! Who is within, here?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: I am within sir, what's your pleasure?

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: To know who is within, besides yourself.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Why, sir, you are no constable, I hope?

lg.l: Oh! Fear you the constable? Then, I doubt not.
You have some guests within deserve that fear,
I'll fetch him straight.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: O' God's name, sir.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Go to. Come, tell me, is not young Knowell here?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Young Knowell? I know none such, sir, o' mine honesty!

lg.l: Your honesty? Dame, it flies too lightly from you;
There is no way but, fetch the constable.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: The constable? The man is mad, I think.

sp.speaker: CASH
sp.p: Ho, who keeps house here?

lg.l: Oh, this is the female copesmate of my son!
Now shall I meet him straight.
Knock, Thomas, hard.
Ho, good wife?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with you?

lg.l: Why, woman, grieves it you to ope your door?
Belike you get something to keep it shut.
What mean these questions, pray ye?
So strange you make it? Is not my husband here?
Her husband!
My tried husband, Master Kitely.
I hope he needs not to be tried here.
No, dame: he does it not for need, but pleasure.
Neither for need, nor pleasure, is he here.
This is but a device, to balk me withal.
Soft, who is this? 'Tis not my son, disguised?
Spies her husband come, and runs to him
Oh, sir, have I forestalled your honest market?
Found your close walks? You stand amazed, now, do you?
I' faith, I am glad, I have smoked you yet at last!
Where is your jewel, trow? In; come, let's see her
(Fetch forth your huswife, dame): if she be fairer,
In any honest judgement, than myself,
I'll be content with it; but, she is change,
She feeds you fat, she soothes your appetite,
And you are well? Your wife, an honest woman,
Is meat twice sod to you, sir? Oh, you treacher!
She cannot counterfeit thus palpably.
Out on thy more-than-strumpet's impudence!
Steal'st thou thus to thy haunts? And have I taken
Thy bawd, and thee, and thy companion,
This hoary-headed lecher, this old goat,
Close at your villainy, and would'st thou 'scuse it,
With this stale harlot's jest, accusing me? To him
Oh, old incontinent, dost not thou shame,
When all thy powers' inchastity is spent,
To have a mind so hot? And to entice,
And feed th' enticements of a lustful woman?
Out, I defy thee, I, dissembling wretch!
Defy me, strumpet. Ask thy pander, here,
Can he deny it? Or that wicked elder?
Why, hear you, sir.
Tut, tut, tut: never speak.
Thy guilty conscience will discover thee.
What lunacy is this, that haunts this man?
Well, good wife B-A-'-D, Cob's wife; and you,
That make your husband such a hoddy-doddy;
And you, young apple-squire; and old cuckold-maker;
I'll ha' you every one before a justice:
Nay, you shall answer it, I charge you go.
Marry, with all my heart, sir: I go willingly.
Though I do taste this as a trick, put on me
To punish my impertinent search--and justly;
And half forgive my son for the device.
Come, will you go?
Go? To thy shame, believe it.
Why, what's the matter here? What's here to do?
Oh, Cob, art thou come? I have been abused,
And i' thy house. Never was man so wronged!
'Slid, in my house, my master Kitely?
Who wrongs you in my house?
Marry, young lust in old; and old in young, here:
Thy wife's their bawd, here have I taken 'em.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: How? Bawd? Is my house come to that? Am I preferred thither? Falls upon his wife and beats her Did I charge you to keep your doors shut, Is'bel? And do you let 'em open for all comers?

lg.l: Friend, know some cause before thou beat'st thy wife,
This's madness in thee.
Why? Is there no cause?
Yes, I'll show cause before the Justice, Cob:
Come, let her go with me.
Nay, she shall go.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Nay, I will go. I'll see an' you may be allowed to make a bundle o' hemp, o' your right and lawful wife thus, at every cuckoldly knave's pleasure. Why do you not go?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: A bitter quean. Come, we'll ha' you tamed.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Well, of all my disguises yet, now am I most like myself, being in this sergeant's gown. A man of my present profession never counterfeits, till he lays hold upon a debtor, and says, he 'rests him, for then he brings him to all manner of unrest. A kind of little kings we are, bearing the diminutive of a mace, made like a young artichoke, that always carries pepper and salt in itself. Well, I know not what danger I undergo by this exploit; pray heaven, I come well off.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: See, I think yonder is the varlet, by his gown.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Let's go in quest of him.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: 'Save you, friend, are not you here by appointment of Justice Clement's man?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Yes, an't please you, sir: he told me two gentlemen had willed him to procure a warrant from his master, which I have about me, to be served on one Downright.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: It is honestly done of you both; and see where the party comes you must arrest. Serve it upon him, quickly, afore he be aware--

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Bear back, Master Matthew.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Master Downright, I arrest you, i' the Queen's name, and must carry you afore a Justice, by virtue of this warrant.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Me, friend? I am no Downright, I, I am Master Stephen, you do not well to arrest me, I tell you, truly: I am in nobody's bonds, nor books, I, would you should know it. A plague on you heartily, for making me thus afraid afore my time.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Why, now are you deceived, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: He wears such a cloak, and that deceived us; but see, here 'a comes, indeed! This is he, officer.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Why, how now, Signior Gull! Are you turned filcher of late? Come, deliver my cloak.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Your cloak, sir? I bought it, even now, in open market.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Master Downright, I have a warrant I must serve upon you, procured by these two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: These gentlemen? These rascals?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Keep the peace, I charge you, in her Majesty's name.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: I obey thee. What must I do, officer?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Go before Master Justice Clement, to answer what they can object against you, sir. I will use you kindly, sir.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: Come, let's before, and make the Justice, Captain--

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: The varlet's a tall man, afore heaven!

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Gull, you'll gi' me my cloak?

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Sir, I bought it, and I'll keep it.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: You will.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Aye, that I will.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Officer, there's thy fee, arrest him.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Master Stephen, I must arrest you.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Arrest me, I scorn it. There, take your cloak, I'll none on't.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Nay, that shall not serve your turn now, sir. Officer, I'll go with thee, to the Justice's; bring him along.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Why, is not here your cloak? What would you have?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: I'll ha' you answer it, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Sir, I'll take your word; and this gentleman's, too, for his appearance.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: I'll ha' no words taken. Bring him along.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Sir, I may choose to do that: I may take bail.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: 'Tis true, you may take bail, and choose--at another time; but you shall not, now, varlet. Bring him along, or I'll swinge you.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Sir, I pity the gentleman's case. Here's your money again.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: 'Sdeynes, tell not me of my money, bring him away, I say.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I warrant you he will go with you of himself, sir.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Yet more ado?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I have made a fair mash on't.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Must I go?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I know no remedy, Master Stephen.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Come along, afore me, here. I do not love your hanging look behind.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Why, sir, I hope you cannot hang me for it. Can he, fellow?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: I think not, sir. It is but a whipping matter, sure!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Why, then, let him do his worst, I am resolute.

div2.head: Scene i
div2.stage: [Enter] CLEMENT, KNOWELL, KITELY, DAME KITELY, TIB, CASH, COB [and] SERVANTS

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Nay, but stay, stay, give me leave; my chair, sirrah. You, Master Knowell, say you went thither to meet your son.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: But who directed you thither?

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: That did mine own man, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Nay, I know not, now: I left him with your clerk, and appointed him to stay here for me.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: My clerk? About what time was this?

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Marry, between one and two, as I take it.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: And, what time came my man with the false message to you, Master Kitely?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: After two, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Very good; but, Mistress Kitely, how that you were at Cob's? Ha?

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: An' please you, sir, I'll tell you: my brother, Wellbred, told me that Cob's house was a suspected place--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: So it appears, methinks; but, on.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: And that my husband used thither, daily.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: No matter, so he used himself well, mistress.

sp.speaker: DAME KITELY
sp.p: True sir, but you know what grows by such haunts, often-times.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: I see rank fruits of a jealous brain, Mistress Kitely; but, did you find your husband there, in that case, as you suspected?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: I found her there, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Did you so? That alters the case. Who gave you knowledge, of your wife's being there?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Marry, that did my brother Wellbred.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: How? Wellbred first tell her? Then tell you, after? Where is Wellbred?

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: Gone with my sister, sir, I know not whither.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Why, this is a mere trick, a device: you are gulled in this most grossly, all! Alas, poor wench, wert thou beaten for this?

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: Yes, most pitifully, an't please you.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: And worthily, I hope: if it shall prove so.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Aye, that's like, and a piece of a sentence. [Enter a SERVANT] How now, sir? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Sir, there's a gentleman, i' the court without, desires to speak with your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: A gentleman? What's he?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: A soldier, sir, he says.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: A soldier? Take down my armour, my sword, quickly: a soldier speak with me! Why, when knaves? He arms himself Come on, come on, hold my cap there, so; give me my gorget, my sword. Stand by, I will end your matters anon-- Let the soldier enter.
Now, sir, what ha' you to say to me?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: By your worship's favour--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Nay, keep out, sir, I know not your pretence, you send me word, sir, you are a soldier: why, sir, you shall be answered here, here be them have been amongst soldiers. Sir, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Faith, sir, so it is, this gentleman and myself have been most uncivilly wronged, and beaten, by one Downright, a coarse fellow about the town here, and for mine own part, I protest, being a man in no sort given to this filthy humour of quarrelling, he hath assaulted me in the way of my peace; despoiled me of mine honour; disarmed me of my weapons; and rudely laid me along in the open streets, when I not so much as once offered to resist him.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Oh, God's precious! Is this the soldier? Here, take my armour off quickly, 'twill make him swoon, I fear: he is not fit to look on't, that will put up a blow.

sp.speaker: MATTHEW
sp.p: An't please your worship, he was bound to the peace.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Why, an' he were, sir, his hands were not bound, were they?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: There's one of the varlets of the city, sir, has brought two gentlemen here, one upon your worship's warrant.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: My warrant?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Yes, sir. The officer says, procured by these two.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Bid him come in. Set by this picture.
sp.stage: [Exit SERVANT. Enter] DOWNRIGHT, STEPHEN [and] BRAINWORM [still disguised as a sergeant]
sp.p: What, Master Downright! Are you brought at Master Freshwater's suit, here?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Aye, faith, sir. And here's another brought at my suit.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: A gentleman, sir. Oh, uncle!

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Uncle? Who? Master Knowell.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Aye, sir! This is a wise kinsman of mine.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: God's my witness, uncle, I am wronged here monstrously, he charges me with stealing of his cloak, and would I might never stir, if I did not find it in the street, by chance.

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Oh, did you find it, now? You said you bought it, erewhile.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: And you said I stole it; nay, now my uncle is here, I'll do well enough with you.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Well, let this breathe a while; you, that have cause to complain there, stand forth: had you my warrant for this gentleman's apprehension?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Aye, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Nay, do not speak in passion so; where had you it?

sp.speaker: BOBADILL
sp.p: Of your clerk, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: That's well! An' my clerk can make warrants, and my hand not at 'em! Where is the warrant? Officer, have you it?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: No, sir, your worship's man, Master Formal, bid me do it for these gentlemen, and he would be my discharge.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Why, Master Downright, are you such a novice, to be served, and never see the warrant?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Sir. He did not serve it on me.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: No? How then?

sp.speaker: DOWNRIGHT
sp.p: Marry, sir, he came to me, and said, he must serve it, and he would use me kindly, and so--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Oh, God's pity, was it so, sir? He must serve it? Give me my long-sword there, and help me off; so. Come on, sir varlet, I must cut off your legs, sirrah. Flourishes over [the kneeling Brainworm] with his long-sword Nay, stand up, I'll use you kindly; I must cut off your legs, I say.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Oh, good sir, I beseech you; nay, good Master Justice.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: I must do it: there is no remedy. I must cut off your legs, sirrah, I must cut off your ears, you rascal, I must do it; I must cut off your nose, I must cut off your head.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Oh, good your worship.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Well, rise, how dost thou do, now? Dost thou feel thyself well? Hast thou no harm?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: No, I thank your good worship, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Why, so! I said, I must cut off thy legs, and I must cut off thy arms, and I must cut off thy head; but I did not do it. So, you said, you must serve this gentleman with my warrant, but you did not serve him. You knave, you slave, you rogue, do you say you must? Sirrah, away with him, to the jail, I'll teach you a trick, for your must, sir.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Good sir, I beseech you, be good to me.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Tell him he shall to the jail, away with him, I say.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Nay, sir, if you will commit me, it shall be for committing more than this: I will not lose, by my travail, any grain of my fame certain.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: How is this!

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: My man, Brainworm!

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: Oh yes, uncle. Brainworm has been with my cousin Edward and I all this day.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: I told you all there was some device!

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Nay, excellent Justice, since I have laid myself thus open to you, now stand strong for me: both with your sword, and your balance.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Body o' me, a merry knave! Give me a bowl of sack. If he belong to you, Master Knowell, I bespeak your patience.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: That is it I have most need of.
Sir, if you'll pardon me only, I'll glory in all the rest of my exploits.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Sir, you know I love not to have my favours come hard from me. You have your pardon; though I suspect you shrewdly for being of counsel with my son, against me.

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Yes, faith, I have, sir; though you retained me doubly this morning for yourself: first, as Brainworm; after, as Fitzsword. I was your reformed soldier, sir. 'Twas I sent you to Cob's, upon the errand without end.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: Is it possible! Or that thou should'st disguise thy language so, as I should not know thee?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Oh, sir, this has been the day of my metamorphosis! It is not that shape alone that I have run through, today. I brought this gentleman, Master Kitely, a message too, in the form of Master Justice's man, here, to draw him out o' the way, as well as your worship; while Master Wellbred might make a conveyance of Mistress Bridget to my young master.

sp.speaker: KITELY
sp.p: How! My sister stol'n away?

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: My son is not married, I hope!

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
sp.p: Faith, sir, they are both as sure as love, a priest, and three thousand pound (which is her portion) can make 'em; and by this time are ready to bespeak their wedding supper at the Windmill, except some friend, here, prevent 'em, and invite 'em home.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Marry, that will I (I thank thee for putting me in mind on't). Sirrah, go you, and fetch 'em hither, upon my warrant.
Neither's friends have cause to be sorry, if I know the young couple aright. Here, I drink to thee, for thy good news. But, I pray thee, what hast thou done with my man Formal?

sp.speaker: BRAINWORM
