sp.p: Faith, sir, after some ceremony past, as making him drunk, first with story, and then with wine (but all in kindness) and stripping him to his shirt, I left him in that cool vein, departed, sold your worship's warrant to these two, pawned his livery for that varlet's gown, to serve it in; and thus have brought myself, by my activity, to your worship's consideration.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p:
And I will consider thee in another cup of sack. Here's to thee, which having drunk off, this is my sentence. Pledge me. Thou hast done or
assisted to nothing, in my judgement, but deserves to be pardoned for the wit o' the offence. If thy master, or any man here, be angry with thee, I shall suspect his ingine, while I know him, for't. How now? What noise is that?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Sir, it is Roger is come home.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Bring him in, bring him in.
What! Drunk in arms, against me? Your reason, your reason for this?

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: I beseech your worship to pardon me: I happened into ill company by chance, that cast me into a sleep, and stripped me of all my clothes--

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Well, tell him I am Justice Clement, and do pardon him; but, what is this to your armour? What may that signify?

sp.speaker: FORMAL
sp.p: An't please you, sir, it hung up i' the room where I was stripped; and I borrowed it of one o' the drawers, to come home in, because I was loath to do penance through the street i' my shirt.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Well, stand by a while. Who be these?

Oh, the young company, welcome, welcome. Gi' you joy. Nay, Mistress Bridget, blush not: you are not so fresh a bride but the news of it is come hither afore you. Master bridegroom, I ha' made your peace, give me your hand; so will I for all the rest, ere you forsake my roof.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: We are the more bound to your humanity, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Only these two have so little of man in 'em, they are no part of my care.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Yes, sir, let me pray you for this gentleman, he belongs to my sister, the bride.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: In what place, sir?

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: Of her delight, sir, below the stairs, and in public: her poet, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: A poet? I will challenge him myself, presently, at extempore:

lg.l: Mount up thy Phlegon muse, and testify,
How Saturn, sitting in an ebon cloud,
Disrobed his podex white as ivory,
And, through the welkin, thundred all aloud.

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: He is not for extempore, sir. He is all for the pocket-muse, please you command a sight of it.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Yes, yes, search him for a taste of his vein.

div2.stage: [They search the pockets of MATTHEW, who resists]

sp.speaker: WELLBRED
sp.p: You must not deny the Queen's Justice, sir, under a writ o' rebellion.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: What! All this verse? Body o' me, he carries a whole realm, a commonwealth of paper, in's hose! Let's see some of his subjects!

lg.l: Unto the boundless Ocean of thy face,
Runs this poor river charged with streams of eyes.
How? This is stol'n!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: A parody! A parody! With a kind of miraculous gift to make it absurder than it was.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Is all the rest, of this batch? Bring me a torch: lay it together, and give fire. Cleanse the air. Here was enough to have infected the whole city, if it had not been taken in time. See, see, how our poet's glory shines! Brighter and brighter! Still it increases! Oh, now it's at the highest; and now it declines as fast. You may see. Sic transit gloria mundi.

sp.speaker: KNOWELL
sp.p: There's an emblem for you, son, and your studies!

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Nay, no speech or act of mine be drawn against such as profess it worthily. They are not born every year, as an alderman. There goes more to the making of a good poet, than a sheriff, Master Kitely. You look upon me! Though I live i' the city here, amongst you, I will do more reverence to him, when I meet him, than I will to the mayor, out of his year. But, these paper-pedlars! These ink-dabblers! They cannot expect reprehension, or reproach. They have it with the fact.

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Sir, you have saved me the labour of a defence.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: It shall be discourse for supper: between your father and me, if he dare undertake me. But, to dispatch away these, you sign o' the Soldier, and picture o' the Poet (but both so false I will not ha' you hanged out at my door till midnight), while we are at supper, you two shall penitently fast it in my court, without; and, if you will, you may pray there, that we may be so merry within as to forgive, or forget you, when we come out. Here's a third, because we tender your safety, shall watch you, he is provided for the purpose.
Look to your charge, sir.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: And what shall I do?

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: Oh, I had lost a sheep, an' he had not bleated! Why, sir, you shall give Master Downright his cloak; and I will entreat him to take it. A trencher and a napkin you shall have, i' the buttery, and keep Cob and his wife company, here; whom I will entreat first to be reconciled, and you to endeavour with your wit to keep 'em so.

sp.speaker: STEPHEN
sp.p: I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: COB
sp.p: Why, now I see thou art honest, Tib, I receive thee as my dear and mortal wife again.

sp.speaker: TIB
sp.p: And I you, as my loving and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p:
Good complement! It will be their bridal night too. They are
married anew. Come, I conjure the rest to put off all discontent. You, Master Downright, your anger; you, Master Knowell, your cares; Master Kitely, and his wife, their jealousy.

lg.l: For, I must tell you both, while that is fed,
Horns i' the mind are worse than o' the head.
Sir, thus they go from me; kiss me, sweetheart.
'See what a drove of horns fly in the air,
Winged with my cleansèd, and my credulous breath!
Watch 'em, suspicious eyes, watch where they fall.
See, see! On heads, that think they've none at all!
Oh, what a plenteous world of this will come!
When air rains horns, all may be sure of some.
I ha' learned so much verse out of a jealous man's part in a play.

sp.speaker: CLEMENT
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well! This night we'll dedicate to friendship, love, and laughter. Master bridegroom, take your bride, and lead; every one, a fellow. Here is my mistress: Brainworm! To whom all my addresses of courtship shall have their reference. Whose adventures this day, when our grandchildren shall hear to be made a fable, I doubt not but it shall find both spectators, and applause.
